fields.description:
I am starting to use Greenhopper for all my task management instead of JIRA, but sometimes I want to open up several cards in new tabs by middle clicking" on the issue key link. But because you guys are opening up the popup via javascript, it just opens up a tab with something like this: "javascript:Boards.viewIssue('LWC-3038')". 

I don't always want to be forced to view/edit full JIRA issues in modal dialogs because I usually need navigation (back & forward controls) when viewing/editing an issue.

Please let me middle click to open cards in new tabs.
fields.summary: When looking at cards in Greenhopper, please let me "middle click" to open the card in a new tab

fields.description:
Greenhopper calculates scope of a version based on the issues that are related to a version.
This is very handy to visualize scope increase (or decrease) using the chart board.

What is missing is the concept of a baseline, so that you can compare the 
scope against what was initially committed to.

When we are running a sprint we do 'in-flight replanning' meaning that we are moving
some stories back to the product backlog because other stories are taking more
time, or because stories are 'below the line'

At the end of the sprint, I'm getting questions like 'at the start of the sprint
we had initially 520hours committed, but the current graphs shows only 460 hours'

At that moment it would be very useful to be able to show:
This is the list of issues we took initally in the iteration, and these have been dropped
'in-flight', to be able to deliver the other priorities, or the way around,
'during this sprint following stories have been added to the iteration'
fields.summary: As a project manager I can compare the scope against a baseline

fields.description:
With Microsoft Project, when a task is delayed (for example because a client delivers some documents 2 days later) then the rest of the tasks involving that project also get delayed with 2 days. However, that feature is not present in GreenHopper.

As we use JIRA to our fullest content, it would be great if this feature could be implemented (maybe via a Jelly Script) in GreenHopper.

Is it possible to create something like this?

fields.description:
Hi, 

We use JIRA and GreenHopper (now JIRA Agile, I guess?). I have been using the SCRUM Ranking field in all of our projects. Now that we've upgraded to v4.0#466, the SORT BY ("Context" options) appears to be broken on the Task Board. I can rank issues properly in the Planning Board, with the context set to "Sort by SCRUM Ranking" but when I switch over to the Task Board with the same context my stories/subtasks are out of order. I have confirmed that the Scrum Ranking is accurate on the stories and tried the "Optimize (repair)" link in the configuration. The ability to sort by Scrum Ranking was working fine before we updated to JIRA4. See attached screenshots. Any suggestions, if we are doing something wrong over here, are welcome - please help! 

Attached: 
planningboard_rightorder.png - Sort by SCRUM Ranking enabled; note the placement of the "Regression Testing" story and tasks at the bottom
ScrumRanking_relativeorder.png - See where the Regression Testing story falls relative to the other stories on the sprint (which are listed right above it)
TaskBoard_outoforder.png - Regardless of what I do, the Regression Testing story is at the top and our other stories are out of order on the Task Board, without changing the context "Sort by SCRUM ranking" at all.
fields.summary: Greenhopper Sort by SCRUM Ranking not working consistently

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I spent a while today going through the configuration steps listed in GreenHopper 101, sections 2 and 3 ("Configuring JIRA and GreenHopper" and "Optional Extra Configuration").

The steps in Section 2 seem to be universal (otherwise why would Section 3 be called "Optional Extra Configuration")?
So, it seems to me that there should be a button that performs those steps.

There could also be an administrator form for specifying which of the optional configurations are desired, and a button to go ahead and do those.
fields.summary: Please automate configuration steps

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Sections 2 and 3 of the "GreenHopper 101" document, titled "Configuring JIRA and GreenHopper" and "Optional Extra Configuration" contain some critical instructions for successfully installng GreenHopper.

Surprisingly I can't find the same information anywhere within the "GreenHopper Installation and Upgrade Guide".  I would expect the Installation steps would tell me everything I need to do in order to have a successfully running GreenHopper installation.  Instead, if I follow ONLY those steps, I will end up fairly confused as to why some features (such as Ranking and Hierarchical Versions) don't work in my intallation.
fields.summary: Installation Guide missing some critical steps (found in GreenHopper 101)

Steps:
1. Login to QA-EAC. Agile gadget is installed there.
2. Create a new page and click on insert/edit macro link. Try to add "agile" gadget from "All" or "External Content" left tab.
3. In the same dialog user get a UI to configure gadget.
4. Try to select a project and save it

Result:
1. Nothing happens, the progress bar keep on going.
2. Try to "login&approve" the gadget, it take you to qa-jac and user click "approve access".
3. Back in confluence, now user can't see any project/filter in agile gadget.

Expected:
1. The gadget should work without any error message.

Add Info:
1. The gadget works fine in JIRA.

fields.description:
This is not easy to reproduce on the latest versions of JIRA.
The problem is that if no versions are found an empty set is returned instead of a null reference. Since GreenHopper only checks the null case, the empty set will trigger this error.

Steps to reproduce:
1) User clicks on "New Card" from Greenhopper in the Marketer product
2) Screen goes to an opaque grey with "Loading" in the foreground.
3) The "Loading" never quits and the user eventually gives up and hits the back button.

The following error appears in the catalina.out log when the issue occurs:

fields.description:
For example, when I'm looking at this page on JIRA Studio, I want to open one of the issues in a new tab or window so I can write a comment. There doesn't seem to be a way to do this.

https://studio.atlassian.com/secure/GetBoardForIssue.jspa?type=TB&key=EMBCWD-104

I think it would be good if the issue key link was a normal issue link, just with the additional GreenHopper functionality added with JavaScript. This would preserve the default behaviour of middle-clicking (or right-clicking) on the issue key to open the issue in a new tab or window in Firefox and Safari. Currently, middle-click opens the task board in another window which is not very useful.

(I'm not sure which version of GreenHopper is running on StAC currently, so you'll need to set the Affects-Version yourself.)
fields.summary: Planning board doesn't offer a way to open an issue in a new tab or window.

fields.description:
We need a way to specify the tasks in a particular sprint in Greenhopper other than using the FixForVersion.

Because of Greenhopper, we need to use Fix Version to record both release version for a ticket (5.1, 5.2, etc.) and sprint number (Sprint 13, 14, 15, 16, etc., all of which are bundled into release 5.1, for example). We use Jira across the enterprise by the support team, product team, engineering team and sales team. All teams need to have access to the Fix Version field (sales and support suggest versions when creating tickets, product team manages what features go in what sprints, engineering team places tickets into sprints). When another team selects an item in the Fix Version select box, they usually accidentally erase the sprint selection, because of the way a select operates. Alternatively, they sometimes think they need to select a sprint. Our Scrummaster spends about 30 minutes a day correcting these mistakes. This was the major con in our purchase decision regarding Greenhopper.

Ideally we'd like to use a custom field (from Jira) to designate the sprint that each ticket is in. That way, we could set up access (permissions) to both items appropriately.
fields.summary: Use a custom field to specify sprints in Greenhopper, rather than FixForVersion

fields.description:
When selecting multiple tasks, such as in the List View of the Planning Board, ctrl-click is supported for multi-select and shift-click for selecting ranges. However, the behaviour is different from the standard for how this is used in other applications (including multi-select fields everywhere else in JIRA).

This leads to some usability awkwardness:
* When selecting a range from a list, in most apps the user clicks on the first item then shift-clicks on the last item. If you do this on the planning board, it selects all items from the start of the list to the clicked item.
* In most apps, an unmodified click on any item will clear the existing selection. On the planning board, the user has to click an item outside the selection and drag it by a few millimetres before the selection is cleared.
fields.summary: Selecting tasks is unintuitive on the planning board

fields.description:
For example,
1) Start at https://qa-jac.atlassian.com/secure/GetBoardForIssue.jspa?selectedProjectId=12200&selectedVersionId=-1&type=VB&id=96860#card_GHS-1714
2) Click "Edit this issue in JIRA". You get a popup dialogue with the full JIRA UI within it.
3) In the dialogue, click Update->Planning Board->"Edit this issue in JIRA".
At this point you have nested dialogues and it becomes a complete mess. 

My expectation is that the dialogue popup would either:
* only contain the "Edit Issue" page without the top menu bar or side toolbar, and close when the editing action is complete, or
* be fully-functional, but pop up in a new tab or window as a new instance of JIRA.
fields.summary: The "Edit this issue in JIRA" dialogue shows the full JIRA interface within a dialogue. As a user, my expectation is that dialogues don't contain menu bars and toolbars within them - that if a full interface is intended, it would pop up in a new tab.

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Follow the instructions here to restrict the Resolutions for a specific workflow step
   http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Resolutions+per+workflow+step
2. On the Task Board, move a top-level issue through the edited workflow step
3. Move a sub-task through the same workflow step

Observed:
The available resolutions are restricted correctly but displayed in reverse order for sub-tasks. 
If you drag a top-level issue to a status that opens the transition window, the transitions are correctly restricted but they are in reverse order.
In Outline view, clicking the link to transition the issue results in a list of all of the resolutions (including the ones you excluded) in the correct order. 

Expected:
The resolutions should be restricted according to the property setting and displayed in the correct order, regardless of issue level or how you transition them.
fields.summary: Restricting resolutions by workflow step works inconsistently for sub-tasks and top-level issues on Task Board

fields.description:
h3. Attendees:
# Nick Muldoon
# Martin Jopson
# JC Huet
# Venuu ??

\\ \\
h3. Exercise:
*1. Open - Check-In (5 min)*

Get everyone to check-in to the retrospective by asking each person to say in one or two words how they feel about the iteration. This way everyone says something from the start and it helps people to continue to be vocal and involved throughout the retrospective.

*2. Brainstorming (20 min)*

Paraphrasing James Shore: Ask the team to think back to the iteration and brainstorm the events that were enjoyable, frustrating, and puzzling, and consider what you'd like more of, less of, and to remain the same. Write each idea on a separate post-it note and don't worry about duplication.

*3. Dumb Mapping & Retrospective objective (15 min)*

Group related post-it notes, assign each group a name and select the most important group and take it into the next iteration as an action
fields.summary: Retrospective - Release 4.2

So far, the information that we have is that this problem only occurs in EAR/WAR distributions on Tomcat 6 or JBoss 4.2.3, [which is based on Tomcat 6|http://www.sfr-fresh.com/unix/www/jboss-4.2.3.GA.zip:a/jboss-4.2.3.GA/readme.html].

We will update this issue when we find more information.

fields.description:
Sometimes during the course of a sprint, there are new tasks that need to be added that were not known during sprint planning.  When we create new issues to represent these tasks, we assign a time estimate (under the "original time estimate" field).  The problem is that the chart board then reflects it as if this estimate was known at the beginning of the sprint.  What we would like to see if a spike in the chart.  The time estimate should be applied based on the date that the issue was created.

This is important in having a true representation of the burndown.  It's valuable to see how the burndown is affected by new tasks arising mid-sprint.

The only known workaround for us is to enter an original estimate of "1 minute", and then set the appropriate "remaining estimate" as the actual time estimate.  But this isn't intuitive...
fields.summary: As a user, I would like the time estimates of new issues added during the middle of a sprint to be reflected as a spike in the burndown chart.

I am a new GreenHopper User currently getting used to it and I've already created a support issue (https://support.atlassian.com/browse/GHS-117) with a couple questions which turned out to be not supported, yet.. and therefore I'm creating Feature Requests for these one by one (to keep them separate from each other).

Particularly, I would suggest that it's possible to to see on the planning board whether a chosen set of features fit (in terms of: a) users' h/day counted towards the b) features planned (and their est. efforts) + c) the non-working days) into the given release date or how much it is under/overbooked (meaning what the real release date would be).

Cheers,
-J

Particularly, I would suggest that it's possible to set time available per day (per project) on a per user level as well .. on top of the global settings (e.g. most developers work 7-8h/day total, most work on one project, but others do work 3h on project A but 5h on project B which runs partially in parallel to project A etc).

Cheers,

Particularly, I would suggest that setting Non-Working days is also possible on a per-user level which means even though non-working days have been set globally, you can override this setting on a per user level (e.g. saturdays and sundays are generally non-working days for all developers, but some opt-in for 6 or 7 working days / week and therefore 95% of the team is fine with 5/days a week, the other 5% should be able to be configured as available 7d/week).

Cheers,
-J

fields.description:
I hope I have the right component here, I'm referring to the versions column on the right side of the Planning Board.

In an effort to divide and conquer our "Unscheduled" bucket we originally were linking stories as dependencies of very broad epics.  We were using ranking in the Unscheduled version to keep everything grouped.  This proved too cumbersome.  For one JIRA seems to have very limited UI for links.  Unlike sub-tasks, linked issues wouldn't drag and drop along with their parents, and you couldn't create links via drag and drop.  Lastly you can't see the parent/children in the card templates as you do with sub-tasks.

As a second attempt we've setup several hierarchical "Backlog" versions to categorize the backlog instead of epics.  They have no start or end dates assigned, but chronologically they're setup prior to our "Release" and "Iteration" versions.  This concept is working fairly well.  Using hierarchical versions new unscheduled stories and epics can be categorized by dragging them into the appropriate child of the master "Product Backlog" version.  Bulk edits work well too.  Further the stats functionality allows us to get an idea of the scope of the various levels of categorization in our backlog.  All in all it works much better than links did, but one minor issue is the pagination of the versions board makes it rather awkward from a usability standpoint.  It never splits where you would want it to.  Also it's less than ideal to have the current release and iteration pushed off the first page.  If we could change the page size, or disable pagination altogether, I believe that would help.
fields.summary: As a GH user I would like to configure the page size of the VersionBoard
